author: oldcanyon3d

title: Cyrus 3D Printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This version has become obsolete. I am currently working on a new version which is stronger and lighter. The new version will have build envelope of 20cm x 20cm x 20cm. If you need to have a bigger print envelope, I would advice to either upgrade to 20mm extrustion profile or openbeams with this design.  
The reason: at higher speeds the makerbeams can cause flexing of the frame which can have influence on the print quality (not major but still).  
Another thing to consider, if you are building this with frames, put dampers on it to reduce the noise of the casing. If you can afford it, go for acrylic, or to play it safe, go for 20mm extrustion/openbeams and then use acrylic casing.   
My advice is, if you like the Cyrus printer, the design, mechanics etc... hold on with building one because the new version will be much better ;)

I Still need to add the BOM list and instructions to assembly it, although if you look at the renders, it's quite straight forward for the people who can't wait for it.  
The files are free for everyone to use, replicate for your mates, your brother, sister, neighbor. But It has it's limitations, no Commercial use of the files thank you :).  
Please if you like this design and you are downloading it, press the like button. It shows some appreciation and gives me motivation :)

title: Cable Mounts For Enclosures / Strain Reliefs

description.text:
These strain reliefs can be used to run an approx. 7mm thick cable into/out of an enclosure. The holes that are drilled into the enclosure should be slightly misaligned so that the printed parts deforms a little and acts as a clamp to secure the cable. I hope you know what I mean ;)
I printed mine in PLA and used M3 mounting bolts. The cable diameter can be increased with tape or the hole can be drilled out to a bigger diameter to match thicker cables.

author: etgo

description.text:
Small feet that simply snap onto the base unit. Print one for each corner and put a thin sheet of rubber anti-slip mat under the feet.  
The feet have been designed to be small and therefore function as dampers, reducing vibrations. The small contact area on the rubber mat creates excellent friction, no movements. They are still strong enough for the printer with a heavy spool on top.
EDIT: V2 feet have been added, see photo with green feet. They are more durable, the originals were slightly too soft.
Print one for each corner of the printer. Put rubber mat under.

comments.text: I am currently using a PB Simple Metal on an IKEA desk and the noise transfer fromt he PB to the desk is awful. I am looking forward to printing up these feet and dampening down the vibration transfer. well done author!

description.text:
The perspex top plate on my printer broke, here is the drawing I created that moves the spool holder to the inside of the printer above the delta arms.  
It also provides mounts to move the extruder steppers much closer to the print head and considerably shorten the bowden tube length.  
Thanks to Rob for helping me with initial drawing.

Get drawing cut out from 2 or 3mm aluminium plate (suggest water cutting). 6M4 screw and nut to connect spool holder to top plate
1-3 rod for spool holder with M6 thread (depending on how many hot ends you have) Relocate bowden steppers to bottom of bracket (Assumes EZStruder mount made by clefranc https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:672280) Use existing screws from top plate to secure new plate to top of printer

I had to rub the edges of the mount off a little so the mount would sit over the door and still allow the door to close.  The mount allows access to the screen and the charging port.  Please remember to print this thing with support.  Enjoy :)

title: Agricola ACBAS storage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a storage soluton for the game Agrcola: All Creates Big and Small. It consists of:
  • a box to hold all the animals. I recommend putting the horse animeeples in the largest chamber because they're big
  • a box to hold the starting tiles and 8 fences to start
  • two boxes, each holding the 3 player tokens and 9 fences
  • a box to hold the feeding troughs (buildings), reed, stone, and wood
  • a box to hold all the tiles from both expansions
    • The man board, two starting boards, and all 6 farm expansions fit on top of this. The score pad fits inside the animals box. The OpenSCAD code can be found here: https://github.com/benhsu/agricola-acbas-storage

author: benhsu

description.text:
This thing is a pair of compound forceps or tweezers. Four "live" joints, consisting of thin flexible sections, are arranged into a diamond pattern. This produces increased mechanical advantage and gripping force.  
I have found that the live joints used in this design are very tricky to produce with a 3D-printer. The fatigue life seems to be very sensitive to the thickness and radius of curvature of the joints. This thing is actually the fourth design iteration that I have been through in order to get acceptable service life from the joints. Under normal usage I get a few hundred cycles of actuation before one of the joints fails; good enough for a disposable tool that prints in 15 minutes.
The forceps should be printed in the given orientation, with more than 25% infill, and 2 perimeters.

comments.text: I've noticed that the material specifications of nylon filaments state that they work well for living hinges. It might be interesting to try nylon with this part.

This was designed to measure the thrust of a c-class model rocket engine. Uses a Vishay 3696 Strain gauge and a 1.5x.125x48 inch aluminum bar. The circular plate is to be placed in a 5 gallon bucket full of water to provide damping.

This thing was made in OpenSCAD with the following code:
translate([0,0,-10])cylinder(30,1,10);
translate([40,0,-10])cylinder(30,1,10);
translate([0,40,-10])cylinder(30,1,10);
translate([40,40,-10])cylinder(30,1,10);
cube([40,1,20]);
difference() { translate([0,40,0])cube([40,1,20]); rotate([90,0,0]) translate([20,20,-60])cylinder(50,8,8); }
cube([1,40,20]);
translate([40,0,0])cube([1,40,20]);
translate([-10,-10,20])cube([60,60,1]);
difference() { translate([0,0,-10])cylinder(6,10,10); translate([0,0,-10])cylinder(3,9,9); }
difference() { translate([0,40,-10])cylinder(6,10,10); translate([0,40,-10])cylinder(3,9,9); }
difference() { translate([40,0,-10])cylinder(6,10,10); translate([40,0,-10])cylinder(3,9,9); }
difference() { translate([40,40,-10])cylinder(6,10,10); translate([40,40,-10])cylinder(3,9,9); }
translate([20,20,10])cube([5,10,5]);
Whether you need supports depends on your 3D printer.

description.text:
For disassembling the center pole on an Advanced Elements™ AirFusion™ Kayak. The pole can be difficult to disassemble (e.g. when it ends up full of sand and water from a failed surfing attempt). This tool makes disassembly easier by holding down the pin and providing a larger non-cylindrical gripping surface. Align with the pole edge and use the circular cutout to rotate into alignment before attaching the tool. I used a M5 x 6mm screw to hold down the pin (it protrudes 1-2mm beyond the cylindrical wall). Printed in transparent red PETG. Advanced Elements™ and AirFusion™ are registered trademarks of their respective owners and are referred to solely for descriptive purposes. Printer: RigidBot Filaments: (full list can be found on thrinter.com)
-- eSun Transparent Red PETG

This thing was created as a 3D printing test, to see how well your 3D printer did prints without supports and with curves. It was made in OpenSCAD with the following code:
difference()
{
translate([0,-25,0])intersection() { sphere(30); translate([-22,-22,-22])cube(44); }
union() { translate([0,-25,-25]) cylinder(50,15,15); rotate([90,0,0]) cylinder(50,15,15); translate([-3,-25,0])rotate([0,90,0]) cylinder(50,15,15);}
}
This should be made without supports, if you want the printing test to work.

A new player species from our tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder. Sort of a preview of a series of models we'll be releasing for our 28mm scale Wayfarer miniature line. In addition to the miniatures, we here at Ill Gotten Games are gearing up for our first rules expansion: Wayfarer: Into the Weird, and we'll be posting updates leading up to all of that on our blog and our Things Beyond Wonder tumbr page, which you should go and follow if you do all that fangled social media stuff. We'll be posting new content (like NPCs, equipment, and spells and such) to the tumblr page, and we've already got a bit of content up there, including a regular Hero Forge NPC feature. If you haven't checked out that program yet, do so. It's great for making Wayfarer characters. description.text: This thing will allow you to attach your GoPro camera to your tripod without having to get two different adapters. The tripod section is a modified version of the one designed by Brianorca - thingiverse.com/thing:5087 . The dimensions are a little different and it doesn't include the hole for bolting onto the bottom of a camera as it's not needed for the GoPro. The GoPro female mount is borrowed from g00bd0g - thingiverse.com/thing:6154

This is untested but I've been told there could be problems with printing it. I don't have a printer to test this with but I thought someone else will think this is useful and be willing to test print it and provide some feed back. One idea is to print the two sections individually and then glue them together. Another idea is to pause printing before it gets to the level area and providing some kid of support for that middle base area.

author: wpns

title: Nautilus gears with involute gearing - customizable

description.text:
! Updated: added profile shifting - just for fun! the logarithmic spiral has wonderful features. As it is its own involute it seems to shout at you: gear me please!! There is more or less one dominant design in the internet which is also available here at Thingverse in multiple remixed versions.
As nobody seems to have ever given it a try to put proper involute gearing (instead of sloppy sine gearing) to this beauty I tried to use my "roll a toothed rack along it" method to provide a customizeable version.
See here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NuWnDpQR3q0 Here my first print: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D6c90TbKyuY Yes, I'm pretty sure I will do a herringbone version in the next days (edit: here it is: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:773764) What you get:
  • a customizable kinetic teaser. Click brackets in and glue them to any surface with gears aligned.
    • any (reasonable) number of teeth
    • any modulus
    • any slope
  • a structured code with a simple API for easy customizing
    • What you need:
  • OpenScad 2015 (dynamic arrays)
  • ShortCuts.scad library (sorry for that, but it simplifies programming so much). Description in: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:644830
  • on ratios larger than about 2.5 a file to draw file the outmost gear for a smoother run
  • a 8 mm drillbit

• the code echos the inner/outer radii and intrinsic gear ratio of the design.
  • Rising the slope value k of the spiral will enlarge it. The one I used to produce the file Nautilus_gears.stl are somehow at the limit from a mechanical point view.
  • if gears hook up at the turnover point, it helps to drawfile the outermost gear a bit. (I did'nt want to pollute the generic software approach with this.)
  • to mount to any surface clip the brackets in and use double faced tape after align

title: NEMA 17 motor mount for 2020 open beam and KP08 bearing

description.text: This is a NEMA 17 motor mount that is used with 2020 extrusion or open beam and a KP08 bearing.  It can be used to make the Y axis drive rod on a printer.  You will need some M3x60 screws, cut to length.  The heads fit into the cutouts.  Use M5 screws to mount to open beam.

comments.text: I'm not quite sure what you are trying to ask, uploading a picture of it under "makes" might help me understand.  Anyway, you simply adjust the distance parallel to the beam by sliding the mount and the holes are elongated perpendicular to the beam to allow a couple mm of adjustment that way.  I recommend using a coupler that tolerates a slight misalignment (like the one I have shown).

author: Technobly

description.text:
The Lidar-Lite from PulsedLight is neat widget, but I found my unit sprays quite a bit of IR outside of the main axis of the collimated laser beam; some internal scattering maybe. As a consequence, a nearby surface can be detected by scattered illumination, even when it is not on-axis.  Also, it wouldn't hurt the receiver to have a sun-shade in place, so I designed this.   Wall thickness is 0.8 mm and with a 0.4mm print head, it works best if you set infill to 0%. OpenSCAD model included.  
UPDATE: v4 has more baffles (# of rings is a parameter), tighter ID of baffle rings, and improved mechanical fit to Lidar case.  
Note that many plastics are translucent at 900 nm, and in fact I could see the beam through the wall with an IR camera before I painted it. For this to work as intended, you need to paint the inside with an opaque flat black paint ( I used "Angelus Brand Acrylic Leather Paint".) This can be tricky to apply given the internal baffle rings, but an old toothbrush worked nicely.

comments.text: This is pretty interesting, did you see any increase in performance from this, or is it strictly for preventing the light from bleeding onto other things and possibly messing with other sensors?
comments.author: Bartimaeus

comments.text: In one configuration I had with a nearby surface (off optical axis) it would only see the nearby surface, until I added this shield tube. I don't think there is any other effect on performance good or bad, besides this special case.  Well, it might help sensitivity if there was a strong interfering light source, like the sun or strong specular reflection, just off axis that would otherwise capture receiver gain. Vertical vs. Horizontal should not make a difference and I haven't seen any.
comments.author: Bartimaeus

title: Mainstays Office Chair Repair - Back Rest Bracket

description.text: I purchased some extremely cheap office chairs (~$20 each) from Walmart last year (Mainstays brand).  The back rest brackets were very poorly made and have started to break, so I whipped up a replacement.

I printed this one in black ABS, 0.3mm, two perimeters, and support enabled (for the overhang inside the bolt holes.  
Unfortunately, I chose 10% infill, and quite high print speed, so it turned out pretty fragile.  
I'd suggest using 30 or 40% infill, and maybe more perimeters (3 or 4) for a stronger part.

author: slai98

description.text: A cutbag entry. A chair/stool made from cardboard and a bag. Good for a kick around chair for the kids to play around with.

• Cut a bunch of cardboard into roughly 9"x14" rectangles. I used 8 layers per board. Some layers can be just a bunch of pieces.

  • Glue the layers together. You need two boards. Stick some books on top to keep everything tight together as the glue dries.

  • Trim the sides if desired. A little scroll saw works great for this.

  • Tape the ends. This is where the weight will be supported.

  • Cut a slot in the middle of the board half way through and as wide as the boards are thick.

  • Cut some tough bag material the width of the chair and long enough to hang over the ends a few inches. Heavy plastic bags like large rice bags tape easily and are quite tough.

  • Tape the plastic to the chair. Repeat on the bottom. The bottom bag is required for strength. It converts bending loads to compressive loads.

  • Sit on it. Though it is intended for kids, I sat on it and it held. It was a little flexy side to side though, so a couple straps on the sides might help.

  • Hover your mouse pointer on the red link at the top left of this page under the "likes" heading, if it changes to a "Like It" link, click on the link:)

  • Repeat step 9 with my other cutbag entries here. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7685 (You know you can't resist the cute kids.)
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7697

comments.text: If you don't have access to a laser cutter, you might want to look up one of your local corrugated board suppliers or a box manufacturer. Most plants have a designer on staff with a cutting table. A cutting table can cut from DXF files with minor conversion, or directly from an HPG or ACS file. If the designer is a bit of geek (very likely), he or she may cut it for you for free from scrap stock if you let them use the file how they want.

description.text:
My definition of Commercial Use is:
ADVERTISING MY ITEMS FOR SALE
i.e. webshop, ebay, etc. ALL other usage is non-commercial, as far as I'm concerned.
Word-of-mouth, requests, 3D hub stuff, all OK, at any quantities. Commercial sales are licensed at 5% of retail price (ex postage & sales tax).
Payments are done monthly through Paypal.
100% of license fees are donated by myself to the MS Society of NZ. If you feel the need for a commercial license, please contact me through the private message function here, including your email address.

Since it has become obvious that most people are printing my 1:200 tanks for wargaming, I decided to redetail some of them to suit the scale. A secondary consideration was to ensure that the details would still be printable on my Form 1 SLA printer at 1:200. These tanks are designed for EXPERTS only. If you don't already know the answer to your questions, please go instead to the 1:200 sets, which are much more forgiving to print. 1:200 tanks pack 1: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:232248 Printed at 0.2mm layers, 0mm support limit, 80degree support angle in ABS on UP plus 2. These models will be added to, on a random schedule. You will find complementary vehicles and guns on TigerAce1945's page:
http://www.thingiverse.com/TigerAce1945/designs

Sexton II GPO Vehicles are either reworked versions of my 1:200 tanks, or newly drawn. All models drawn in Solidworks. Parasolid versions included in the zip files All vehicles printed sitting on their tracks. All turrets printed with their guns horizontal.
Printed at 0.2mm layers, 0mm support limit, 80degree support angle in ABS on UP plus 2. Obviously a finer Z resolution would look better, but it's a matter of time-to-print which determined my choice. Sdkfz 250-b1 printed with 45degree support angle to prevent the inside being filled in with support structure. I advise that you in all cases clear out the support from between the tracks underneath the vehicle first. This will enable the outside support structure to be levered off without too much trouble.
In cases where the support doesn't want to come free, cut carefully down through the supports beside the model with a sharp xacto knife to break the support. Printing on the Form 2, I sat the vehicles and turrets up on their tails, set contact points to 0.5mm. Just keep an eye on where Preform places the contact points, because sometimes the positions are less than optimal, and need to be edited...

comments.text:
I re-scale for bolt action all the time, this is what I do you might have an easier way.
find the actual length from Wikipedia in meters ie 5,89M
multiply by 1000
then divide by the scale you want ie 56 for 1/56 or 48 for 1/48 I use 1/48 btw...
that gives you a measurement in millimeters ie 122.70833333333mm or 123mm rounding up a little for cura
comments.author: BeardyWargameSupplies

comments.text: When I am getting models ready to print in Cura, I have expanded them 174.2%, but then check the width and length against Wikipedia to make sure it matches.
comments.author: BeardyWargameSupplies

comments.text:
Bolt Action is supposedly 1:56 scale. This is the scale Warlord uses.
100/56 = 1.7857 = 178.57%

comments.text:
You can freely post modified versions. Just please remember to tag them as derivatives.
I use Solidworks, which is a high-end industrial program, so I doubt you'll be using that. Try 123D or Blender.

comments.text: Or for those who either use Autocad processes or like a mid range 3d CAD, Fusion 360 is a good option. More advanced than 123D but migrating is easy as the methodology is similar

comments.text: how does everyone paint these? i've tried painting mine directly and the printed texture keeps showing. Would quick washing it in acetone help to smooth the surfaces a bit?
comments.author: hendrikdc

comments.text: Starting with the obvious, if you want as good a finish as possible, make sure you print at the best z resolution your printer can handle. Even 0.15mm vs 0.2mm shows very visible improvement.
comments.author: hendrikdc

comments.text:
oh! I misunderstood, my apologies, I haven't used the wash with acetone aproach, did use nail polish remover, tough i am not very much convinced. honestly I'm new to 3d printing and am still experimenting. there is a similar process (haven´t used it yet) that gives you more control than washing it (uneven soaking of the acetone, or leaving marks with the brush) and is safer than eating highly flamable acetone: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=biLVyGDvisM
Also would like to try to wash, or dip (or something) the model in resin, in my case I'll use some polyester resin leftover I have around.
comments.author: hendrikdc

comments.text: I usually give them a coat with a primer, basically spray paint them with the matte color suitable for the occasion, it has many uses, first among them is to make the paint (acrylic in my case) stick to the model. just a as example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RDbwrBZ61YU
comments.author: hendrikdc

comments.text: I'm aware to always prime my miniatures before painting them.  My question was more about smooting the 3D printed surfaces  before priming/painting. Do you spend hours sanding the surfaces? I've hear about dunking the ABS model in acetone for 3 seconds would work as well so smooth (or rather chemically melt/ dissolve ) the surface

comments.text: How much printing material do they use?I've got no prior experience with 3d printing but am curiis to print sole (hopefully cheap? ) hanomags!
comments.author: Fox40

comments.text:
Depends on the scale. At 1/56th an m4 Sherman will use approx 30metres of filiment, depending on fill %
A hangman would prob around 15-18metres of filiment.
You can buy abs for £10 for 1kg which is approx 400metres.
So in abs cost a medium tank would be under £1, a hanomag would be approx 50p
comments.author: hendrikdc

comments.text: Also depends on the infill. Printing at 100% vs 20% will take ~5x more material.
comments.author: Fox40

comments.text:
I did say it depends on the fill %
Although why anyone would print at anything beyond 30% for these is beyond me.
Most of mine are printed at 15% fill
comments.author: klowsen

comments.text: 15% is a good fill to use but if you did print one at nearly 100% fill, say by accident, you would notice that it has a really nice heavy feel about it!

description.text:
There won't be much call for this tiny print job but for those who need it...
Some time ago, I purchased the "Double Lens Loop" from Harbor Freight to assist me when work in very small projects. They don't appear to sell this device any longer but you can still get it in various locations on the Internet (amazon, ebay etc.). I quickly found out that they wouldn't clip to my readers because the frame was too thin. Today I printed a small block that allows the loop to attach easily and stay in place.

author: exi0dus

description.text:
This intuitive design assembles perfectly to house 7" tablets and up. Made to be sturdy and universal. I have tested this with the Samsung Tab 3, Kindle HD 2nd Generation, Kindle Fire HD 7.   
Please let me know which tablets you've tried this with and I'll add it to the list!

Hey it's Kyle mayne, this is my first upload! Let me know how I did in the comments. Find me on instagram : whysofrail (I post similar material on my account) First things first.. Make sure it fits! The length of Universal Tablet Holder is 16.5cm(16.5mm). I would recommend adding a 5mm tolerance on each end and make sure that your tablet is at LEAST 17.5cm(175mm) in length. Please let me know if this confuses you! Now that we know your tablet is fit for this holder. Download the source .STL files. You only need to download the following files: R_TAB_HOLDER.stl
L_TAB_HOLDER.stl
SQUARE_DOWEL.stl NOTE **
If you want you can download the blender (.blend) source files you can find them in the files. Also if you want to get a sneak peak what the source files contain, checkout the image gallery and I have previews in the there. Plug the *.stl files into your favorite program (Slic3r) and generate your gcode. I left all the values default and I made sure that supports were enabled (helps for the square holes that the dowels slide into). PLEASE MAKE SURE YOU PRINT x7 of the SQUARE_DOWEL.stl because this design requires that quantity. After your 3d print has finished clean up the edges with a straight edge knife,box knife whatever you use (if you desire). Slightly bevel the ends of the square dowels to make sure that they seat perfectly into the left and right part of the holder. This design doesn't require glue or any adhesive. If you have troubles with the dowels popping out bevel the edge more or make sure that the square insets on the left and right holder are fully cleared out and free the support plastic we generated. Feel free to glue these dowels so that they never come out. It's all personal preference and is up to you! I didn't have any issues with them popping out.

title: GCodePrintr and IP Webcam Tablet Stand for Deltabot

description.text:
Designed to hold my tablet in the optimal positions to use GCodePrintr and IP Webcam on a Double30 Deltabot.
http://gcodeprintr.dietzm.de/
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.pas.webcam&hl=en IP Webcam Pro is great for streaming the tablets camera over the network, but the shape of a deltabot makes it prefereable to turn the tablet in to portrait mode instead of landscape. Short Z height making a minimal print. The wood dowels are cheap, look nice and can be found everywhere..

I recommend using your slicer program to "mirror" one print of each of the two files to have a better match on your finish. Pictures make assembly easy, use a dab of super-glue at the junction between dowels and printed parts. I included my source files. To make design changes, modify the DWG in draftsight, and export DXF's for the SCAD file to import as described here:
http://wiki.skillhouse.org/index.php/Draftsight-2D-OpenSCAD-3D-Print

I bought a mounting arm for my Cintiq 13 HD. As any owner of that tablet knows, the device does not include a VESA mount behind, making it impossible for it to be strapped to a monitor mount, ergotron/some other brand's arm, or a support of any sort that uses the VESA standard. I figured there was an easy, cheap way to do this safely, and I'm sharing it so others can do it as well.  
The tablet is held from top and bottom, and when correctly assembled: No hardware actually touches the tablet. You won't damage it. I've stress-tested it to and fro and it works like a charm. ¡Enjoy!  
Disclaimer: READ THE INSTRUCTIONS.
If you like the projects on my Thingiverse, consider giving a tip. Not only I will appreciate it immensely, I promise to put it to good use. Thanks for your consideration!

MATERIALS:
I used 3 mm MDF. Acrylic can work, but I liked the fact that MDF has some more give and is cheaper. I spray-painted it before the laser-cutting. CUTTING:
Cut at your laser cutter of choice. Gather the pieces. An important note: The "brackets" that repeat several times to produce thickness do have a right side up. make sure that the bolts enter without much hassle. HARDWARE FOR ASSEMBLY:
You're going to need some extra hardware for this. It's very cheap though.
-Washers (I used neoprene and steel washers for a better grip)
-Wing Nuts or just nuts to strap it on the back.
-IMPORTANT: Adhesive rubber stoppers. These separate the cut hardware from the tablet and protect it from wear and tear.
  • I used steel caps for aesthetics, but it sure is not a requirement.
    • ASSEMBLY:
  • First, Add bolts and washers to the largest part. the Engraved side goes towards you.
  • Paste rubber stoppers at all corners, and at equal distances. You want the rubber stoppers to be TALLER than the bolts that'll strap this to the Vesa mount. I used Flat head screws to make this easier.
  • Put the tablet over this. Make sure it fits snugly.
  • Take the TOP bracket (With the Märchen logo) and orient it. You'll need to paste more rubber stoppers at the lower corners, and at least at two places in-between. Make sure that the stoppers are near the lower border.
  • Do the same for the lower bracket.
  • Find out how many separators (remember: they have a right side up) you'll need. Test-assemble the entire setup and find out how many you need. The Rubber stoppers might change how many you need, but my setup uses 4 per side.
  • Assemble and make sure everything is snug, but not too tight. use wing nuts to secure everything in place.
  • Mount your tablet on the VESA mount or arm. Use wing nuts to tighten. Give it a whirl and make sure the tablet does not fall. TRY to separate it to make sure all works.
    -ENJOY! and send me a picture.
    • ADAPTING:
    You can use this with other devices! Just adapt and re-measure, the principle works the same way.

description.text:
Replacement bridge saddle for my 34-year old Yamaha FG-340 II folk guitar whose neck had warped (CCW direction toward the 6th) over time. It was becoming a pain to play bar chords over the lower frets.   
Google Sketchup (.SKP) source file is included in case you want to make your own. See instructions.

To make your own:

  • Measure or estimate where on the saddle and by how much, do you need to reduce (measure from where the saddle is exposed)

  • Remove saddle, measure length and where each string used to sit.

  • Mark out each string along that saddle length.

  • Measure height of each "string mark" and make raised points along that drawing line.

  • Join them up, and there you have it - it should look like your original bridge saddle.

  • Decide how much you want to trim, raise the thickness (to match original saddle) then round off each leading edge.

title: MicroScrab quad V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the new version of scrab quad. The new things are:
-Lipo at the bottom, more easy to replace, and more flexible about size.
-Distance between top plate and body reduced, and good to place Rx, Vtx, osd and other electronics.
-All parts except arms and middle body are redesigned
-Added a camera fixed tilt angle support (two versions, 25º and 15º) This is a ligth design, then I recommend to use light motors (DYS 1806) and ligth ESC (blue 12A). With a 1250 mAh 3S lipo and all FPV stuff, the weight is under 500 grams. All grey parts in second picture are not printable. I recomend to use M2 X 20 screws to assamble (16 units with bolt) and the antivibration are the blue ones at hobbyking. Also, you need two 4mm tubes GF or CF, as long as you want This is the indoor test video: https://youtu.be/yZbZIEfiWvY And this is a fly video, with final crash test: https://youtu.be/5R-_umZLiJw. As you can see, the upper plate is disarmed, but no other damages (except minor sky support damage)

remixed_from.author: gtrick90
remixed_from.title: E3D v6 hotend complete mount (with groove) for Kossel mini 3D printer

title: Kossel grooved mount for round cooling duct

description.text:
I wanted to try the "Cooling Duct That Works!" by doctek on my Kossel with E3D-v6 hotend so I remixed this part with "E3D v6 hotend complete mount (with groove) for Kossel mini 3D printer" by gtrick90. The result is a grooved mount with a way to mount the cooling duct. You will need the cooling duct and one (or more) of the link parts from doctec's thing. [update 2015-04-17]
I found that the Kossel Effector from gtrick90's thing was 1mm too thick (at least according to the official drawings of the E3D-v6) and as a result I had to file down the groove mount to be able to fit it on my printer.
Uploaded a modified version of the effector that is 7mm thick instead of 8mm, for a better fit. [update 2015-04-27]
The cooling duct was not spot-on in the center around the hot-end, so I uploaded a new version of the grooved mount where the mounting part for the duct have an offset of 2mm to the left.
Let me know if this works better for you as well :-)
An easy print, no support needed.

title: Front Knuckle Spacers for Kyosho Mini-Z MR-02/MR-03

description.text: A set of spacers for the front knuckles of the Kyosho Mini-Z MR-02 and MR-03 RC models. These are used for regulating the height of the front suspension as well as limiting the maximum travel of the car's wheels. We have the spacers available in three different sizes in order to help you get finer tuning ability, so here are spacers height 0.5 mm, 1 mm and 1.5 mm. You can also combine multiple spacers to get the desired height adjustment. Make sure you use finer resolution for printing these out as they are quite small and need to be precise, we have used 0.1 mm layer height for a great result. Also you might need to lower the extrusion speed a bit while 3D printing the part for best results. Designed by http://minirc-project.com/

Still working on it so things will change. A redesign of gzumwalt marblevator design with a wheel for the lifting instead of the step`s. Check out the video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OP2o0gtpFbM Original design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:60778 Have also attached my current sketchup drawing But it is not printed or tested. Ask if you have any questions. Update 26.04.15: Added v2 of the wheelbase and base. Check the stls for the one you want. The idea with v2 is that you can pop the wheelbase out of the base and insert it into a new base with difrent track. Added starting track, you need one off the 3 to be your first track. Added the track witch is the same as gzumwalt`s but they have two smal notches on each side to attach the arms. Added the arms for the tracks see Tressel stl.

Parts: Motor: https://www.pololu.com/product/2366 (Maybe consider changing to a slower motor to slow down the wheel speed.)
Bearing: 608ZZ (Not needed can print the bearing part instead)
Switch: https://www.pololu.com/product/1407
Battery holder: https://www.pololu.com/product/1150 ( This is the one i used Cut it in two an soldered on a wire. Would recommend to buy one for one single AA battery instead.
9,5mm steel balls: http://www.ebay.com/itm/BALL-BEARINGS-9-5MM-3-8-PACK-X-100-/200970728122?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item2ecac9f2ba
M8 bolt an nut. Want to try printable version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647

title: Name or phone number tag, necklace for your pet, cat, dog. Free standing lace.

description.text:
You need an embroidery machine to create this tag. Hoop a water soluble stabilizer (tested on Ultra Solvy).
You also need a software to change the text. Search on google for some free software. My recommendation would be EmbroideryModder, it is free and open source.

I use Embird software and tested with Brother embroidery machine. After the stiching is done on a water soluble stabilizer, cut out the stitched piece and leave in water for ten minutes or so, so that the stabilizer dissolves. Dry it and then use it.

comments.text: As a Cigar and tobacco enthusiast, I personally agree that it is annoying that you cannot get cars to come without those stupid little plugs. Smoking in your car reduces the resale value, and the smell will never really come out. I would rather my car come with a half dozen USB plugs for all the random electronic critters that seem to gather in my pockets!!
comments.author: woofpickle

description.text: Your 3D you!

The Viktoria Apartments in Seattle, Washington is a 24-story, 297,000 square foot residential tower with 249 residential units. The building offers one level of retail and lobby space, five levels of above-ground parking, 17 levels of residential units, and one rooftop terrace level with common amenity areas including party rooms, theatre space, fitness center, yoga room, business center, and leasing offices.The building is a LEED certified concrete structure that includes a glass and precast concrete exterior façade. This project was modeled for Turner City 2014, which was created entirely by Turner employees. Click here to see this interactive City and to watch a fly-thru, which includes this project: http://www.turnerconstruction.com/turnercity Click here to learn more about this project:
